short_description: Slow-cooked Moroccan stew with lamb, apricots, and warming spices.
steps: Brown lamb.
Add spices.
Slow cook.
Add fruit.
cooking_tips: Low and slow.
Tagine pot ideal.
nutrition_benefits: Iron-rich lamb, antioxidant spices, natural sweetness from fruit.

short_description: Fluffy semolina with seven vegetables and tender meat.
steps: Steam couscous.
Make vegetable stew.
Layer and serve.
cooking_tips: Fluff couscous.
Seven vegetables traditional.
nutrition_benefits: Balanced meal with protein, fiber, and complex carbs.

short_description: Hearty Moroccan soup with lentils, chickpeas, and tomatoes.
steps: Simmer lentils.
Add chickpeas.
Thicken with flour.
cooking_tips: Ramadan staple.
Dates on the side.
nutrition_benefits: High fiber, plant protein, low fat.

short_description: Sweet and savory pie with chicken, almonds, and cinnamon in phyllo.
steps: Poach chicken.
Make filling.
Layer phyllo.
Bake.
cooking_tips: Brush phyllo well.
Dust with sugar.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from chicken, healthy fats from almonds.

short_description: Sweet green tea with fresh mint, poured from a height.
steps: Rinse tea.
Add mint and sugar.
Steep.
Pour from height.
cooking_tips: Pour from height for foam.
Fresh mint essential.
nutrition_benefits: Antioxidants from tea, digestive mint.

short_description: Smoky eggplant and tomato dip with cumin and paprika.
steps: Roast eggplant.
Cook with tomatoes.
Mash and season.
cooking_tips: Char eggplant.
Serve warm or cold.
nutrition_benefits: Low calorie, fiber-rich, antioxidants.

name_en: Chicken Tagine with Olives and Preserved Lemons
short_description: Succulent chicken braised with tangy preserved lemons, briny olives, and aromatic spices. This iconic Moroccan dish showcases the perfect balance of savory, sour, and spiced flavors.
steps: Cut chicken into pieces and season with salt, pepper, ginger, and turmeric.
Sauté grated onion in olive oil until soft.
Add chicken pieces and brown on all sides.
Add garlic, cilantro, parsley, and enough water to cover.
Simmer covered for 45 minutes until chicken is nearly done.
Cut preserved lemons, discard pulp, and slice the peel.
Add preserved lemon peel and olives.
Continue cooking uncovered for 15 minutes.
Reduce sauce until thick and flavorful.
Garnish with fresh cilantro and serve with bread.
cooking_tips: Use ripe Moroccan olives for authentic flavor.
The preserved lemons are key - they add a unique tangy depth.
Serve in the tagine pot for traditional presentation.
nutrition_benefits: High protein from chicken. Olives provide healthy fats. Preserved lemons add probiotics from fermentation.

short_description: Spiced meatballs simmered in a rich tomato sauce with eggs poached on top. This beloved Moroccan comfort food is perfect for sharing with warm bread.
steps: Mix ground meat with grated onion, parsley, cumin, and spices.
Form into small meatballs about 1 inch in diameter.
Grate tomatoes or blend them.
Cook tomatoes with olive oil, garlic, and remaining spices.
Simmer until sauce thickens, about 15 minutes.
Add meatballs to the sauce.
Cover and cook for 20 minutes until meatballs are done.
Make small wells in the sauce, crack eggs into them.
Cover and cook until egg whites are set.
Serve immediately with crusty bread.
cooking_tips: Don't overcrowd the meatballs - cook in batches if needed.
The eggs should be runny for dipping the bread.
A tagine pot keeps everything warm at the table.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from meat and eggs. Tomatoes provide lycopene. Spices have anti-inflammatory properties.

short_description: A ceremonial dish of shredded msemen pancakes with lentils and tender chicken in a fenugreek-spiced broth. Traditionally served for new mothers and special celebrations.
steps: Soak fenugreek seeds overnight, then drain.
Cook chicken with onions, spices, and fenugreek until tender.
Cook lentils separately until soft.
Remove chicken and shred the meat.
Add lentils to the chicken broth and simmer.
Tear msemen into pieces and arrange on a large platter.
Ladle the lentil broth over the bread to soak it.
Top with shredded chicken.
Drizzle with melted butter.
Serve immediately while hot.
cooking_tips: Fenugreek is essential for authentic flavor but use sparingly.
The bread should absorb the broth but not become mushy.
Traditionally served communally from one platter.
nutrition_benefits: Fenugreek is known for boosting milk production in nursing mothers. Lentils provide iron and fiber. A nourishing, complete meal.

short_description: A modern coastal variation of the classic pastilla, featuring a delicate mix of shrimp, fish, and vermicelli wrapped in crispy warqa pastry.
steps: Cook vermicelli according to package directions, drain.
Sauté onions in butter until caramelized.
Add seafood, spices, and herbs. Cook until seafood is done.
Mix seafood with vermicelli.
Brush a pan with butter, layer phyllo sheets.
Add seafood filling in the center.
Fold phyllo over filling, brush with butter.
Flip onto a baking sheet and brush top with butter.
Bake at 375°F until golden, about 25 minutes.
Dust with powdered sugar if desired.
cooking_tips: Don't overcook the seafood - it will cook more in the oven.
Keep phyllo covered with damp towel while working.
The sweet-savory combination is traditional.
nutrition_benefits: Seafood provides lean protein and omega-3 fatty acids. A lighter alternative to traditional meat pastilla.

short_description: Flaky, buttery square Moroccan pancakes with crispy layers. These versatile flatbreads are perfect for breakfast with honey or as an accompaniment to tagines.
steps: Mix flour, semolina, salt, sugar, and yeast.
Add water and knead to a soft, smooth dough.
Divide into balls and let rest 15 minutes.
Mix softened butter with oil for brushing.
Flatten each ball on oiled surface very thin.
Brush with butter mixture, fold into thirds.
Fold again into a square, let rest.
Flatten each square gently.
Cook on a griddle until golden on both sides.
Serve warm with honey or jam.
cooking_tips: The thinner you stretch, the flakier the result.
Oil your hands to prevent sticking.
Can be stuffed with meat or cheese before cooking.
nutrition_benefits: Provides carbohydrates for energy. Semolina adds texture and some protein. Best enjoyed in moderation due to butter content.

short_description: Spongy Moroccan pancakes covered in tiny holes, perfect for soaking up honey and butter. These one-sided crêpes are a beloved breakfast treat.
steps: Blend semolina, flour, yeast, baking powder, sugar, and salt.
Add warm water and blend until smooth batter forms.
Let rest 30 minutes until bubbles form on surface.
Heat a non-stick pan over medium heat.
Pour batter to form a thin pancake.
Cook only on one side until holes form and surface is dry.
Do not flip - the bottom should be smooth.
Melt butter with honey for serving.
Stack pancakes and drizzle with honey butter.
Serve warm.
cooking_tips: The batter must be smooth - use a blender.
Don't flip - the holes are the defining feature.
Serve immediately for best texture.
nutrition_benefits: Semolina provides complex carbohydrates. Honey adds natural sweetness with antioxidants. A traditional breakfast energy booster.

short_description: Whole roasted lamb seasoned with cumin and butter, cooked until the meat falls off the bone. This celebratory dish is the centerpiece of Moroccan feasts.
steps: Make slits in the lamb and insert garlic cloves.
Mix butter with cumin and paprika.
Rub the lamb inside and out with butter mixture.
Season generously with salt.
Roast over an open fire or in a large oven.
Baste frequently with butter mixture.
Cook for 4-5 hours until meat is falling off bone.
Let rest 30 minutes before serving.
Serve with small bowls of cumin and salt for dipping.
Guests eat by pulling meat with their hands.
cooking_tips: Low and slow is the secret to tender meat.
Basting creates the crispy, flavorful exterior.
Traditionally cooked in a pit oven called tandir.
nutrition_benefits: Excellent source of protein. Lamb provides iron and B vitamins. Cumin aids digestion.

short_description: Crispy triangular pastries with savory or sweet fillings. These fried or baked treats are popular as appetizers or desserts in Moroccan cuisine.
steps: Cook ground beef with onion and spices until done.
Add beaten eggs and stir until scrambled into the meat.
Add parsley and adjust seasoning.
Cut phyllo into long strips.
Place a spoonful of filling at one end.
Fold into triangles by folding corner to corner.
Seal edge with water or egg wash.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot as an appetizer.
cooking_tips: Keep phyllo covered while working to prevent drying.
Can also be baked at 375°F for a lighter option.
Sweet versions use almond paste and honey.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from meat and eggs. Best enjoyed as an appetizer in moderation.

short_description: Flower-shaped fried cookies coated in honey and sprinkled with sesame seeds. These intricate sweets are essential during Ramadan.
steps: Toast sesame seeds and grind half of them.
Mix flour with ground almonds, ground sesame, cinnamon, and saffron.
Add melted butter and orange blossom water.
Knead to a smooth dough, rest 30 minutes.
Roll dough thin and cut into strips.
Fold and shape each strip into a flower pattern.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Immediately dip hot cookies into warm honey.
Sprinkle with whole sesame seeds.
Let cool on a rack.
cooking_tips: The shaping takes practice - watch tutorials first.
Warm honey coats better than cold.
Store in airtight container for weeks.
nutrition_benefits: Sesame seeds provide calcium. Almonds add protein and healthy fats. Honey offers natural sweetness.

short_description: A rich, no-bake mixture of toasted flour, almonds, sesame, and honey. This energy-packed sweet is traditionally served during Ramadan and celebrations.
steps: Toast flour in a dry pan until golden, stirring constantly.
Toast almonds and grind coarsely.
Toast sesame seeds and grind.
Toast anise seeds.
Mix all toasted ingredients in a large bowl.
Add cinnamon and powdered sugar.
Mix in melted butter and honey.
Knead until mixture holds together.
Press into a mound or individual shapes.
Dust with powdered sugar before serving.
cooking_tips: Toast flour slowly to avoid burning.
The mixture should clump when pressed.
Keeps for months in an airtight container.
nutrition_benefits: High in energy from nuts and honey. Almonds provide vitamin E. Sesame offers calcium and minerals.

short_description: A refreshing finely diced salad of tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers, and onions dressed with olive oil and lemon. The perfect accompaniment to any Moroccan meal.
steps: Dice all vegetables into very small uniform pieces.
Finely chop the parsley.
Combine vegetables in a bowl.
Whisk olive oil, lemon juice, cumin, and salt.
Pour dressing over vegetables.
Toss gently to combine.
Let sit 10 minutes for flavors to meld.
Serve chilled or at room temperature.
cooking_tips: The smaller the dice, the more authentic.
Add a pinch of cayenne for heat.
Best served fresh the same day.
nutrition_benefits: Rich in vitamins from fresh vegetables. Olive oil provides heart-healthy fats. Low in calories.

short_description: A smoky roasted pepper and tomato salad with garlic and spices. This versatile Moroccan condiment is perfect as a dip or side dish.
steps: Roast peppers and tomatoes until charred.
Peel the charred skins from vegetables.
Chop the roasted vegetables roughly.
Sauté garlic in olive oil until fragrant.
Add roasted vegetables and spices.
Cook down until thickened, about 20 minutes.
Mash to desired consistency.
Stir in fresh cilantro.
Serve warm or at room temperature with bread.
cooking_tips: Char the vegetables well for smoky flavor.
Can be made ahead - flavors improve overnight.
Adjust spices to taste.
nutrition_benefits: Roasted peppers are rich in vitamin C. Tomatoes provide lycopene. A healthy, flavorful side dish.

short_description: A warming spiced lentil soup with tomatoes, ginger, and a hint of cinnamon. This nourishing soup is a staple of Moroccan home cooking.
steps: Sauté diced onion and celery in olive oil.
Add ginger, turmeric, cumin, and cinnamon.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook briefly.
Add rinsed lentils and vegetable broth.
Bring to boil, then simmer for 30 minutes.
Blend partially for creamy texture.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve with lemon wedges and fresh cilantro.
Drizzle with olive oil before serving.
cooking_tips: Red lentils cook faster than brown.
The soup thickens as it sits - add more broth when reheating.
A squeeze of lemon brightens all the flavors.
nutrition_benefits: Lentils are high in plant protein and fiber. Turmeric has anti-inflammatory properties. A nutritious, filling meal.

short_description: Fresh fish marinated in chermoula, a vibrant herb and spice paste, then baked with vegetables. A beloved dish from coastal Morocco.
steps: Blend cilantro, parsley, garlic, spices, lemon juice, and oil for chermoula.
Marinate fish in half the chermoula for 1 hour.
Slice potatoes and tomatoes.
Layer potatoes in a baking dish, season.
Place marinated fish on top.
Add tomato slices around fish.
Spoon remaining chermoula over everything.
Bake at 375°F for 35-40 minutes.
Fish is done when it flakes easily.
Serve with extra lemon wedges.
cooking_tips: Chermoula can be made ahead and refrigerated.
Sea bass, snapper, or tilapia work well.
The potatoes should be tender and absorb the flavors.
nutrition_benefits: Fish provides lean protein and omega-3 fatty acids. Herbs add antioxidants. A healthy, complete meal.

short_description: Traditional round Moroccan bread with a crispy crust and soft interior. This essential bread accompanies every Moroccan meal.
steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water.
Mix flours with semolina and salt.
Add yeast water and olive oil to flour.
Knead for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Divide into two balls.
Flatten each into thick rounds.
Let rise covered for 1 hour.
Prick tops with a fork in a pattern.
Bake at 400°F for 25-30 minutes until golden.
Cool on a rack before cutting.
cooking_tips: The semolina adds a nice texture.
Traditional bread is baked in a communal oven.
Perfect for scooping up tagine sauces.
nutrition_benefits: Whole wheat adds fiber. Semolina provides protein. Essential carbohydrates for energy.

short_description: Diamond-shaped semolina cookies stuffed with date paste and dipped in honey. These North African sweets are especially popular during Ramadan.
steps: Mix semolina with melted butter and orange blossom water.
Add enough water to form a soft dough.
Let rest 30 minutes.
Mix date paste with cinnamon.
Roll dough into logs, fill with date paste, seal.
Roll gently to smooth.
Cut at an angle into diamond shapes.
Score the top decoratively.
Deep fry until golden.
Dip hot cookies into warm honey.
cooking_tips: Don't overfill or they'll burst while frying.
Traditional scoring creates a beautiful pattern.
Store in an airtight container.
nutrition_benefits: Dates provide natural sweetness and fiber. Semolina offers carbohydrates. Honey adds antioxidants.

short_description: Spiced meat skewers grilled over charcoal, a beloved street food throughout Morocco. Simple yet incredibly flavorful.
steps: Cut meat into 1-inch cubes.
Cut lamb fat into smaller pieces.
Mix cumin, paprika, and salt.
Thread meat and fat alternately on skewers.
Season generously with spice mixture.
Grill over hot charcoal, turning frequently.
Cook until charred outside, pink inside (for lamb).
Serve with sliced onion and cumin for dipping.
Garnish with fresh parsley.
Serve with fresh bread.
cooking_tips: The fat pieces keep the meat moist.
High heat creates the characteristic char.
Dip in cumin salt before each bite.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein. Iron from red meat. Simple preparation preserves nutrients.

short_description: A rich, sweet tagine of lamb with honey, raisins, and ras el hanout, traditionally prepared for Eid al-Adha. The perfect balance of sweet and savory.
steps: Cut lamb into large chunks.
Season with ras el hanout, salt, and saffron.
Brown lamb in butter with onions.
Add water to cover, simmer for 2 hours.
Add honey, raisins, and cinnamon.
Continue cooking until sauce is thick and glossy.
Toast almonds until golden.
Transfer to serving dish.
Top with toasted almonds.
Serve with crusty bread.
cooking_tips: The sauce should be thick and caramelized.
Low and slow cooking develops the flavors.
Traditional for Eid celebrations.
nutrition_benefits: Protein-rich lamb. Raisins provide iron. Almonds add healthy fats and vitamin E.

short_description: A creamy dried fava bean soup flavored with garlic and cumin, drizzled with olive oil. This humble, nutritious soup is beloved breakfast street food.
steps: Soak fava beans overnight, drain.
Cook beans with water and garlic until very soft.
Blend until smooth and creamy.
Season with cumin, paprika, and salt.
Thin with water to desired consistency.
Serve in bowls.
Drizzle generously with olive oil.
Sprinkle with extra cumin and paprika.
Serve with fresh bread for dipping.
cooking_tips: The soup should be thick but pourable.
Quality olive oil is essential for finishing.
Street vendors top with a dollop of argan oil.
nutrition_benefits: Fava beans are high in plant protein and fiber. Olive oil provides healthy fats. Very filling and nutritious.

short_description: A hearty white bean stew with tomatoes and cumin. This comforting Moroccan staple is nutritious, filling, and delicious.
steps: Soak beans overnight, drain.
Cook beans until almost tender, about 1 hour.
Sauté onion and garlic in olive oil.
Add grated tomatoes and spices.
Cook sauce for 15 minutes until thickened.
Add cooked beans with some cooking water.
Simmer together for 20 minutes.
Adjust seasoning and consistency.
Stir in fresh cilantro.
Serve with fresh bread.
cooking_tips: Don't add salt until beans are almost cooked.
The stew should be thick and rich.
Can add preserved lemon for extra flavor.
nutrition_benefits: White beans provide protein and fiber. Tomatoes add lycopene. A filling, nutritious vegetarian meal.

short_description: Crispy fried potato patties seasoned with cumin and herbs. These popular street food bites are perfect in sandwiches or as a snack.
steps: Boil potatoes until tender, drain and mash.
Add eggs, minced garlic, parsley, and cumin.
Mix in flour until dough forms.
Shape into small patties.
Heat oil for deep frying.
Fry patties until golden brown on both sides.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with harissa.
Often stuffed into sandwiches with vegetables.
cooking_tips: Don't overwork the potato mixture.
Fry at medium heat for even cooking.
Serve immediately for best crispness.
nutrition_benefits: Potatoes provide potassium. Eggs add protein. A satisfying street food snack.

short_description: Crumbly Moroccan cookies with a cracked top, made with almonds, semolina, or coconut. These melt-in-your-mouth treats are flavored with orange blossom water.
steps: Mix ground almonds with powdered sugar.
Add eggs, melted butter, and orange blossom water.
Mix in baking powder and lemon zest.
Refrigerate dough for 30 minutes.
Roll into small balls.
Place on baking sheet, slightly flatten.
Bake at 350°F for 12-15 minutes.
Cookies should be pale with cracked tops.
Cool completely before removing from pan.
Dust with powdered sugar.
cooking_tips: Don't overbake - they firm up as they cool.
The cracks on top are the signature look.
Store in an airtight container.
nutrition_benefits: Almonds provide healthy fats and protein. A satisfying sweet with some nutritional value.

short_description: Light, airy Moroccan doughnuts without a hole, fried to golden perfection. These street food favorites are best eaten warm, dusted with sugar or drizzled with honey.
steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water.
Add flour and salt, mix to a sticky dough.
Knead for 5 minutes until smooth but still sticky.
Cover and let rise for 1 hour until doubled.
Oil your hands generously.
Take a handful of dough, form a ring shape.
Stretch the ring gently.
Fry in hot oil until golden on both sides.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve immediately with honey or sugar.
cooking_tips: The dough should be very sticky - that's correct.
Keep hands well oiled when shaping.
Serve immediately for best texture.
nutrition_benefits: Provides quick energy. Best enjoyed as an occasional treat. A beloved Moroccan comfort food.

short_description: Elegant crescent-shaped pastries filled with almond paste and perfumed with orange blossom water. These delicate sweets are Morocco's most refined cookies.
steps: Make dough with flour, melted butter, and orange blossom water.
Knead until smooth, rest 30 minutes.
Grind almonds finely with powdered sugar.
Add orange blossom water and cinnamon to almonds.
Mix until almond paste forms.
Roll dough very thin.
Shape almond paste into small cylinders.
Wrap dough around filling, form crescent shapes.
Pinch ends to points.
Bake at 350°F for 12-15 minutes until barely colored.
cooking_tips: The dough must be paper thin.
Don't let them brown - they should stay pale.
Store in an airtight container for weeks.
nutrition_benefits: Almonds provide protein and vitamin E. Orange blossom water has calming properties. A refined treat.
